blog.content:
By now, most everyone has heard the old adage, "Don't fight the Fed".  If you haven't, and are not sure what it means, it simply refers to the fact that it generally doesn't pay to go against what the US Central Bank (the Fed) is doing in and for the markets.  

Over the past 3 months, they have expanded their balance sheet by buying all sorts of securities in the primary and secondary markets., which ultimately adds "liquidity" to financial markets.  And we all know what affect that liquidity has had on the financial markets over the past 3 months.  It is important to know that the Fed's balance sheet is theoretically unlimited so we are conditioned to not look at it or care whatsoever. 

But, what if, the Fed's balance sheet starts to shrink and liquidity is technically reduced?  Would markets sell off? 

We are about to find out:  

![paultepsich](https://res.cloudinary.com/highrock/image/upload/v1596296252/paultepsich_bef1e374dc.jpg)
